questionOriginal: What is a coronavirus?
questionText: What is a coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. There are different types of coronaviruses.  Some types of coronavirus are more common in people and some versions are more common in animals. Rarely, a type of the virus that was common in animals can spread to people. "Coronavirus Disease 2019” (which is shortened to "COVID-19") is an example of a type of coronavirus that has recently spread to humans.     [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is novel (new) coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
questionText: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
answerOriginal: People are more likely to get a severe case of COVID-19 if they are:  -Older than 65 years old -Living in a nursing home or long term care facility -Pregnant -In a prison or jail  People are also more likely to get a severe case if they have a health problem such as:  -Lung disease -Asthma -Diabetes -Sickle cell disease -Liver cirrhosis (liver scarring) -Recent chemotherapy -A weaker immune system   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
questionText: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
answerOriginal: If you think you had contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine yourself for at least 14 days (or two weeks) so that you don't spread the disease. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get symptoms 1 to 14 days after being exposed. If you have any symptoms related to COVID-19, you should self-isolate and talk to your health care provider.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are Covid-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
questionText: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
answerOriginal: The symptoms of COVID-19 and flu are very similar. Both can cause fever, cough, and shortness of breath. To know for sure if you have COVID-19, you will need to get tested. questionOriginal: How likely am I to catch COVID-19?
questionText: How likely am I to catch COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea.  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all.   Older people (those who are 65 or older) and people with health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart problems are more likely to get very sick from COVID-19.   If you or someone you know has one of these problems, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away  -Starting to feel confused  -Can't wake up from sleeping  -Lips or face look blue   If someone has one of these severe symptoms, they need care right away.   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Can vodka be used as a hand sanitizer?
questionText: Can vodka be used as a hand sanitizer?
answerOriginal: Vodka usually does not contain enough alcohol to be an effective hand sanitizer. Make sure any hand santizer you use has at least 60% alcohol, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Any hand sanitizer that has less than 60% alcohol will not work well against the virus. Soap and water are always the best way to clean your hands.

questionOriginal: Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You could be at higher risk of catching COVID-19 if many people have gotten COVID-19 near where you live. You could also have a higher risk if you visit places where many people are getting sick with COVID-19.  Right now, in most places, the risk of catching COVID-19 is still low. But this is changing quickly in many cities and areas around the world.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Will my parents be at risk if I visit them?
questionText: Will my parents be at risk if I visit them?
answerOriginal: Every situation is different, but in general, you should only be around people who you are living with. Follow the guidelines from authorities where you live and keep your parents' health status in mind. If you are not able to see family in person, you may be able to talk on the phone, have video calls, or send them letters.  [[Would you like more information about Should I visit my parents in a senior home?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: How can I protect myself on a plane?
questionText: How can I protect myself on a plane?
answerOriginal: Try not to travel if you do not need to. If it is essential to travel, try to avoid contact with sick passengers, stay as far away from other passengers as you can, avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth, and wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. You should also wear a cloth face covering at the airport and on the plane.  [[Would you like more information about Should I avoid traveling?]]

questionOriginal: What can I do during quarantine?
questionText: What can I do during quarantine?
answerOriginal: Most people are not used to being at home all the time. It's normal to feel feel bored or unsure of what to do. Some things to do during quarantine include:  1. Reading. If you do not have books at home, look for e-books and audiobooks. 2. Find a new hobby or start an art project 3. Learn to cook a new meal 4. Talk on the phone or have video calls with friends or family 5. If it is allowed in your area, go for a walk. Make sure to practice social distancing.  6. Try to set a routine during the day, such as eating meals and going to bed at the same time each day.  [[Would you like more information about What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Should I visit my parents in a senior home?
questionText: Should I visit my parents in a senior home?
answerOriginal: You should not visit a senior home right now. Most senior homes do not allow visitors at this time. This is because people at the senior home are at high risk due to age and underlying health conditions. You might be able to talk with your family over the phone or with a video call. To learn more, you should contact the senior home to find out how they are handling the COVID-19 response and how you can talk to your family.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Will healthcare workers be more isolated because they are exposed to the virus on a daily basis?
questionText: Will healthcare workers be more isolated because they are exposed to the virus on a daily basis?
answerOriginal: Healthcare workers must watch their health closely and follow directions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. This is true especially if they are exposed to people with COVID-19. Many healthcare workers choose to self-isolate from their families to reduce the chance that they will infect their family members.  Lots of healthcare workers are also feeling mentally isolated and stressed during this time. Many healthcare workers have to put the needs of other people in front of their own. It is important for them to practice self care and to take care of their mental health. Some examples of how to practice self care during and after work include:  1. Checking in with colleagues, family, and friends 2. Taking short breaks to relax and manage stress 3. Regular peer consultation and team check ins 4. Taking breaks to take care of your body 5. Using helpful self-talk 6. Focusing efforts on what you can control 7. Trying to accept situations you cannot change 8. Staying patient, tolerant, and hopeful  [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: What are the best cleaners to remove coronavirus germs?
questionText: What are the best cleaners to remove coronavirus germs?
answerOriginal: Clean and disinfect things that people touch a lot on a normal basis. For some surfaces, you can use soap and waters. You can also use household bleach, alcohol solutions with at least 70% alcohol, or common household products to wipe down surfaces. Keep household cleaners locked and away from children so they don't eat or drink it by accident.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and my family?]]

topic: COVID-19 How to Protect Yourself / Your Family / Your Community
questionOriginal: What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?
questionText: What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Here are some tips for coping with anxiety about COVID-19:  1) Get your facts straight. Stay up-to-date with news about COVID-19 from trusted sources. Be careful about what you read on the internet, especially on social media.   2) Keep things in perspective. Although you’ll want to stay informed about COVID-19, focus on what you can control. Take a break from media coverage or social media if you find yourself panicking about the news or an article you just read. If talking about COVID-19 upsets you, change the topic when you can. 3) Be self-aware. Being self-aware of your feelings helps to ease anxiety. 4) Try to keep a regular schedule. Routine makes most people, especially children, feel safe. Stick to normal sleep and meal times. 5) Do things that make you happy, like reading a book, watching your favorite television show, or playing a board game with your family. If you are not in quarantine, take a walk - a little fresh air is always a good idea! 6) Stay connected with family and friends through video chats and phone calls.

questionOriginal: There are no cleaning supplies at the store - what should I do?
questionText: There are no cleaning supplies at the store - what should I do?
answerOriginal: You may have had trouble finding cleaning supplies at the stores lately. If there are no cleaning supplies at stores near you, you can ask store employees when they expect their shelves to be restocked and try shopping around that time. You may also be able to order supplies online.   [[Would you like more information about What types of cleaning products should I use to protect against COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
questionText: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
answerOriginal: If you only have mild symptoms, it is safest to stay home. Most people with mild symptoms from COVID-19 are able to recover at home without medical care.  To keep the virus from spreading, you should: -Avoid public areas -Stay home, except to get medical care -If you think you need to go to the clinic or hospital, call before you go.    If you get one of these severe symptoms, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away -Starting to feel confused -Lips or face look blue

questionText: Can you die from getting COVID-19?

questionOriginal: Am I at greater risk of adverse COVID-19 outcomes if I am pregnant?
questionText: Am I at greater risk of adverse COVID-19 outcomes if I am pregnant?
answerOriginal: Doctors don't yet know for sure if pregnant women have a higher risk of having severe symptoms or long-term effects if they get COVID-19. But it is always important for pregnant women to protect themselves from getting sick. Proper hygiene such as washing hands can help reduce the risk of getting infected of spreading the virus to others.  If you are pregnant and concerned about COVID-19, talk to your doctor.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What types of jobs or workplaces are considered essential during the shelter in place order?
questionText: What types of jobs or workplaces are considered essential during the shelter in place order?
answerOriginal: Essential businesses are business that will have to stay open during the COVID-19 pandemic. Even if they stay open, they might need to make some changes to keep people safe. Businesses and government agencies decide which workers are considered essential. Examples of jobs or workplaces that are allowed to stay open include:   1. Grocery stores 2. Hospitals and mobile emergency units 3. Doctor’s offices  4. Utility companies 5. Law enforcement 6. Banks and credit unions 7. Gas stations  [[Would you like more information about How do I know if I am essential?]] [[Would you like more information about What actions should businesses take to prepare for community spread of COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Do I need to close my business if a positive case of COVID-19 has been identified?
questionText: Do I need to close my business if a positive case of COVID-19 has been identified?
answerOriginal: To decide if you need to close your business due to a case of COVID-19, you should talk to your local health department to decide what type of risk you face. questionOriginal: Are children immune to COVID-19?
questionText: Are children immune to COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Right now, most experts think that children can get the virus at the same rates as adults. But children usually don't get as sick as adults. If a child gets COVID-19, their symptoms are going to be similar to the symptoms adults get. These include fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea are also possible.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Closing schools helps to slow the spread COVID-19. The purpose of closing schools is to prevent students from passing the virus to each other, and then having students pass it to their families. Please keep up with local news media sources, as they will share news about school closures. If schools are closed, your child should stay home. They should avoid groups of people and avoid visiting friends or public places.  [[Would you like more information about How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect my child from COVID-19?]]

questionText: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
answerOriginal: It is important to talk with your child about what is going on. This is a hard time and children will have questions. Stay calm, talk to them about the outbreak, and tell them what you are doing as a family to stay safe.
answerText: It is important to talk with your child about what is going on. This is a hard time and children will have questions. Stay calm, talk to them about the outbreak, and tell them what you are doing as a family to stay safe.

questionOriginal: Can I take my child to the playground?
questionText: Can I take my child to the playground?
answerOriginal: Right now, experts recommend staying away from the playground because there are many germs at the playground. Children can still play outside, but they should not be in large groups (more than 10 people). They should wash their hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

questionOriginal: Should children wear masks?
questionText: Should children wear masks?
answerOriginal: Children under the age of 2 years should not wear any type of masks. Because babies' airways are smaller, breathing through a mask is even harder on them and they are more likely to suffocate if they use a mask. Older infants or young toddlers are not likely to keep the mask on and will likely try to remove it. This will mean they are touching their face more and could infect themselves with the virus. It is safest to keep children at home and follow social distancing.  [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
questionText: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
answerOriginal: Children and adults have the same COVID19 symptoms, although children might not get as sick as adults. Children might get a fever, runny nose, or cough. Some children have had vomiting or diarrhea. We are still learning about how COVID-19 affects children.  [[Would you like more information about how can i protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

questionOriginal: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
questionText: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You can protect your child by having them wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds and avoid people who are sick. They should also stay away from people outside your home. This means you should avoid playdates, playing on public playgrounds, or being physically close to friends.  You should also clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot in household common areas like tables, chairs, and doorknobs. Wash clothes and plush toys frequently.  [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
questionText: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: From what doctors know now, children are not at a higher risk of Covid-19 than adults. Children can become sick with it, but not as often as adults. Most children who have gotten sick with COVID-19 have had mild symptoms, like fever, runny nose, and cough. Some have also had vomiting and diarrhea.  We are still learning if children with some underlying medical conditions may have a higher risk.  [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Does being able to hold your breath for 10 seconds or more without coughing or feeling discomfot mean you are free from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) or any other lung disease?
questionText: Does being able to hold your breath for 10 seconds or more without coughing or feeling discomfot mean you are free from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) or any other lung disease?
answerOriginal: Being able to hold your breath without coughing or discomfort does NOT tell you whether you have COVID-19. The best way to tell if you have COVID-19 disease is with a laboratory test. You cannot tell with this breathing exercise, which can even be dangerous. If you think you may have been infected, contact your healthcare provider to get tested.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Can you recover from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)?
questionText: Can you recover from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)?
answerOriginal: Catching COVID-19 does NOT mean you will have it for life. Most people who catch COVID-19 can get better at home and won't have the virus in their bodies after they have recovered. If you catch the disease, make sure you treat your symptoms. If you have difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, or any other severe symptoms, call your health care provider or seek emergency care.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: How do I clean and disinfect linens, clothing, and other items that go in the laundry?
questionText: How do I clean and disinfect linens, clothing, and other items that go in the laundry?
answerOriginal: Here are some tips for cleaning laundry:  1. Wear gloves when touching dirty laundry from an ill person and then throw away your gloves after using them. If you use reusable gloves, those gloves should be only used for cleaning and disinfecting surfaces for COVID-19 and should not be used for other household purposes.  2. Wash your hands with soap and water right after you take off the gloves. If you cannot use gloves while doing laundry, wash your hands after touching laundry. 3. Try not to shake dirty laundry. This could spread the virus through the air. 4. Wash items at the warmest possible water setting. 5. Dry laundry completely 6. You can wash laundry from an ill person with other people's items. 7. Clean and disinfect clothes hampers.  8. If possible, line the clothes hamper with a bag that you can throw away or wash.  [[Would you like more information about How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: How do I clean and disfect electronics?
questionText: How do I clean and disfect electronics?
answerOriginal: For electronics such as cell phones, tablets, touch screens, remote controls, and keyboards, follow the instructions on the device for how to clean and disinfect them. If you cannot find instructions, consider using alcohol based wipes or sprays with at least 70% alcohol to clean touch screens. Dry surfaces all the way. Make sure it is safe to use alcohol based cleaners and that it will not damage your electronics. Consider using covers for electronics. questionOriginal: Will ingesting soap bubbles kill COVID-19 in my lungs?
questionText: Will ingesting soap bubbles kill COVID-19 in my lungs?

questionOriginal: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
questionText: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If you are caring for someone with COVID-19 at home, prevent the spread of germs, treat symptoms, and monitor for emergency signs.   1. Prevent the spread. If possible, have the sick household member use a separate room and bathroom. Have the sick person stay away from other people and pets as much as they can.  Don't share personal items like towels, dishes, and food. If the person needs to be around other people, they should wear a facemask. If they cannot wear a facemask, others should wear one while in the same room. The sick person should stay at home except to get medical care.   To protect yourself, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth. Disinfect all surfaces that are touched often, like tabletops and doorknobs, using cleaning sprays or wipes. If laundry is soiled, wear disposable gloves and keep laundry away from your body while washing. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol.    2. Treat symptoms. Most people  with COVID-19 can get better with rest and drinking plenty of fluids. Symptoms usually last a few days and get better after a week. Keep track of symptoms, especially fevers.   3. Monitor for emergency signs. Contact a health care provider right away if they have one of these severe symptoms: -Trouble breathing  -Shortness of breath  -Chest pain or pressure that won't go away -Feeling very tired or unable to wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  If someone in your house has one of these severe symptoms or something that worries you, please contact your medical provider. In the case of an emergency, call 911 and tell the dispatcher that the person has or might have COVID-19.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Does the virus stay on clothing?
questionText: Does the virus stay on clothing?
answerOriginal: Researchers found that the virus can stay on some surfaces for up to 72 hours, but the study didn’t include fabric. It is best to have a pair of outside clothes to wear on errands and remove them when you come home. Wash your clothes frequently.   [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]
answerText: Researchers found that the virus can stay on some surfaces for up to 72 hours, but the study didn’t include fabric. It is best to have a pair of outside clothes to wear on errands and remove them when you come home. Wash your clothes frequently.   [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: How long does the virus stay in paper money and coins?
questionText: How long does the virus stay in paper money and coins?
answerOriginal: We don't know for sure how long the virus can last on coins and paper money. In laboratory studies, scientists found that it could last up to 4 hours on copper (similar to coins) and up to 24 hours on cardboard (similar to paper). It is unclear how long the virus can last on surfaces in the real world. It is best to wash your hands well after handling money.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
questionText: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is the best way to protect yourself and your family from getting sick! Wash your hands regularly, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, going to the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you do not have soap and water, use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: How can I protect myself and others?
questionText: How can I protect myself and others?
answerOriginal: To protect yourself and others from COVID-19, you should:  1. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty.  2. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.  3. Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).  4. Stay away from people who are sick.  5. When you are sick, stay at home - except when getting medical care.  6. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away.  7. If 'social distancing' measures have been recommended where you are, be certain to follow them.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: How long should we self-quarantine for?
questionText: How long should we self-quarantine for?
answerOriginal: Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days.   Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days. Remember, every time you could have been exposed to the virus means you should restart your 14 day clock for quarantine.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?]]

questionOriginal: Any advice about how to minimize risk during grocery shopping trips or getting takeout.
questionText: Any advice about how to minimize risk during grocery shopping trips or getting takeout.
answerOriginal: Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can stay on surfaces and objects. Here are some tips to reduce risk while grocery shopping:   1. Shop when stores are less busy 2. Disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store  3. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from others while shopping 4. Avoid touching your face while shopping  5. While paying, avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. Wipe down debit or credit cards after using them. 5. Wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water  You can also see if delivery services are available in you area. In some areas, you may be able to buy directly from local farmers and producers.  [[Would you like more information about Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?]]

questionOriginal: Does a mask actually help if I am sick or not?
questionText: Does a mask actually help if I am sick or not?
answerOriginal: The virus can spread between people even if they do not have symptoms or feel ill. questionText: Can I move in with family if we have all been symptom free for 14 days?

questionOriginal: Can I move during a pandemic?
questionText: Can I move during a pandemic?
answerOriginal: You should check with your moving company and local officials to see if there are travel or group restrictions that would prevent you from moving.  While you may be allowed to move during COVID-19, please consider the following things to determine whether it is in your best interest:  - Is your current home unsafe or unfit to live in?  - Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  - Will you be in close contact with others during your trip?  - Are you or the people you are moving with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  - Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If you need to move, these same questions can help you plan to be as safe as possible. questionOriginal: How do I take my temperature?
questionText: How do I take my temperature?
answerOriginal: You can take your body temperature a few different ways. The most common ones are the mouth, the ear, the armpit, and the rectum. The best way for adults is orally, which uses a thermometer in your mouth. This is the most accurate way.  To take your temperature using a digital thermometer:  1. Place the tip of the thermometer in your mouth, under the tongue and close to the middle.  2. Keep your lips closed and hold the thermometer in place with your tongue and fingers. Don't bite it.  3. Based on the thermometer type, you will hear a beep in about 30 seconds or some other signal. You can take the thermometer out.  4. Take the thermometer out and read the temperature.  In most adults, a fever is an oral temperature above 100.4°F (38°C).   [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]]

questionOriginal: Is it safe to use ride-sharing services (e.g. Lyft, Uber)?
questionText: Is it safe to use ride-sharing services (e.g. Lyft, Uber)?

questionOriginal: Does drinking hot water kill COVID-19?
questionText: Does drinking hot water kill COVID-19?

questionOriginal: Should someone continue to self-isolate even if they are feeling better?
questionText: Should someone continue to self-isolate even if they are feeling better?
answerOriginal: If you have symptoms of coronavirus, you'll need to self-isolate for 7 days. After 7 days, you no longer need to self-isolate if you do not have a high temperature. If you still have a temperature, keep self-isolating until your temperature is back to normal. You do not need to self-isolate if your only symptom after 7 days is a cough, because a cough can last for several weeks after the infection is gone.  If you live with someone with symptoms of COVID-19, you should self-isolate for 14 days starting the day their symptoms started. If more than one person at home has symptoms, self-isolate for 14 days starting the day the first person's symptoms started. If you get symptoms, self-isolate for 7 days starting when your symptoms began, even if this is longer than the original 14 days. If you do not get symptoms, you can stop self-isolating after 14 days.

If you do not get symptoms, you can stop self-isolating after 14 days.

questionOriginal: How do I quarantine myself if I live with my family or roommates?
questionText: How do I quarantine myself if I live with my family or roommates?
answerOriginal: If you or someone you live with is infected, or at high risk of being infected, you should stay in another room as much as you can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible.  Other ways of protecting yourself include:  -Avoid sharing household items like dishes, cups, towels, and bedding -Wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol -Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot -Wash laundry frequently and thoroughly -If you have pets, the infected person should not care for them -Don't have visitors in your home -The person who is sick should wear a mask if possible

questionOriginal: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
questionText: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
answerOriginal: If you do not have soap and water, you can use:  -Household disinfectant. Please be sure to follow instructions on the product's label.  -Alcohol solutions that contain at least 70% alcohol -Diluted bleach solution, depending on the surface you want to clean. Check the label to make sure you can use the solution for disinfecting and that it is not expired. Follow the instructions on the label. Leave the solution on the surface for at least 1 minute. Do NOT mix bleach with ammonia or any other cleaner.  [[Would you like more information about How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: Should I go to the ER or my physician directly if I'm infected?
questionText: Should I go to the ER or my physician directly if I'm infected?
answerOriginal: If you believe you have COVID-19, please contact your health provider. Your healthcare provider will help you determine if you should be tested and if your symptoms are mild enough to be safe at home. Most people with mild symptoms of COVID-19 can get better at home. If this is not an emergency, this symptom checker by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) can help you find out if you could have COVID-19. It can also help you decide what to do next. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/index.html  If you have one of these symptoms, you should call 911 or emergency medical services to seek care right away and tell the dispatcher that you think you have COVID-19:  -Trouble breathing -Pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away -Feeling confused -Lips or face that look blue   [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms? ]]

questionOriginal: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
questionText: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
answerOriginal: If you are worried about your mental health during this time, you are not alone. If you are concerned that you may be at risk of harming yourself or someone else, please call 911 or the emergency services in your country.   Here are some ways to help cope with stress: 1. Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories. 2. Take breaks from social media. 3. Take care of your body by eating healthy meals, exercising at home, and avoiding alcohol and drugs. 4. Make time to unwind and do things that you enjoy. 5. Spend time talking to others, while practicing social distancing. If you have a phone or Internet access, call someone you trust and talk to them about how you are feeling.  If you are feeling overcome by sadness, depression, or anxiety, please get help from a trusted provider. If you have a mental health condition please continue your treatment. If you want or plan to harm yourself or others, please call an emergency number or hotline.

questionOriginal: What are the general recommendations for routine cleaning and disinfection of households with People Isolated in Home Care (e.g. Suspected/Confirmed to have COVID-19)?
questionText: What are the general recommendations for routine cleaning and disinfection of households with People Isolated in Home Care (e.g. Suspected/Confirmed to have COVID-19)?
answerOriginal: If someone in your home might have COVID-19, you should learn about COVID-19 symptoms and how to prevent its spread. Here are some tips:  1. Clean and disinfect high touch surfaces every day. Some examples of high touch surfaces are tables, chairs, doorknobs, light switches, phones, tablets, touch screens, remote controls, keyboards, handles, desks, toilets, and sinks. 2. If possible, the infected person should stay in a different room and use a separate bathroom from others in the home. If they cannot use a separate bathroom, the bathroom should be cleaned and disinfected after each use by an ill person. 3. If the infected person can safely clean their own room and bathroom, the caregiver can provide supplies like tissues, paper towels, and household cleaner. 4. If the infected person cannot clean their own room and bathroom, the caregiver should avoid contact with the ill person as much as possible. They should only clean their room when needed and wait as long as possible after use by an ill person to clean shared bathrooms or common  spaces.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What precautions should I take if I am pregnant?
questionText: What precautions should I take if I am pregnant?
answerOriginal: If you are pregnant, here are some steps you can take to stay healthy:  1.        Wash your hands. You’ve heard this advice over and over. But that’s because it works! Keeping hands clean can stop the virus in its tracks. 2.        Practice “social distancing.” Stay away from other people and large groups. If you need to be around others, try to keep 6 feet (2 meters) away. 3.        Get the flu shot. It won’t protect you against COVID-19. But it will lower your risk of getting the flu since the flu can also cause problems for pregnant moms. 4.        Go virtual. Try to have virtual (online) or phone visits with your doctor whenever you can. Spending less time in the waiting room and office can help you stay healthy. However, you might still need an in-person visit for some things like ultrasounds or blood work. 5.        Call your doctor if you’re coughing. If you have symptoms like cough, fever, or shortness of breath, call or email your doctor. They will decide if you should be tested for COVID-19 and tell you what to do next.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]  [[Would you like more information about What precautions should I take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?]]

questionOriginal: Can pregnant women with COVID-19 pass the virus to their fetus or newborn?
questionText: Can pregnant women with COVID-19 pass the virus to their fetus or newborn?
answerOriginal: No evidences show that virus can pass from mother to fetus before delivery. A report looked at nine pregnant women in China in their third trimester with pneumonia caused by COVID-19. None of the mothers developed severe illness. Two babies did show some signs of distress, but all nine babies were born alive and healthy. Also, they all tested negative for coronavirus.

questionOriginal: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
questionText: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
answerOriginal: Here are six practical ways to stretch your dollars at the grocery store.  Make Your Menu: Time permitting, write out a basic meal plan for the week and the groceries you’ll need for it.  Respect the Freezer : frozen fruits and vegetables are a cost-effective source of nutrition.  Play the Sale: Look for discounts, coupons, and sales, especially on store brands, which usually cost less.  Go Big: Buy in bulk when you can (e.g., purchase a whole chicken instead of just chicken breasts). Freeze what you don’t immediately need.  Go Home: If you have time, prepare food yourself instead of buying prepared or frozen meals. Thirty minutes will give you enough time to bring together simple, tasty meals.  Read the Fine Print: Compare unit prices (dollars per pound or per ounce) listed on price tags to find the cheapest brand.  Hold the Steak: Because meat can be a relatively expensive source of protein, look to supplement it with plant-based sources of protein like beans, quinoa, and whole-wheat pasta.  Shop the Season: Off-season produce is almost always more expensive and of inferior quality.

questionOriginal: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
questionText: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
answerOriginal: Right now there is no evidence that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can live on surfaces for up to 72 hours, if you are worried you can disinfect food packaging after bringing it home from the store. You should also follow the usual food safety steps like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
questionText: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
answerOriginal: Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can stay on surfaces and objects. Here are some tips to reduce risk while grocery shopping:   1. Shop when stores are less busy 2. Disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store  3. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from others while shopping 4. Avoid touching your face while shopping  5. While paying, avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. Wipe down debit or credit cards after using them. 5. Wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water  You can also see if delivery services are available in you area. In some areas, you may be able to buy directly from local farmers and producers.  [[Would you like more information about Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?]]

questionOriginal: Does cooking food kill COVID-19?
questionText: Does cooking food kill COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. There is currently no evidence that it can be spread through food. In general, you should practice good hygiene and food safety practices. This means cleaning surfaces that are used a lot, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food.

questionOriginal: Should food workers who are ill stay home?
questionText: Should food workers who are ill stay home?
answerOriginal: You should stay home and tell your supervisor if you have symptoms of COVID-19. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend that workers who have COVID-19 symptoms stay home and not come to work. Workers should not come back to work until they do not have a fever anymore and have no other symptoms for at least 24 hours, without taking medicine for fever or cough. A fever is a temperature of 100.4° F [37.8° C] or greater using an oral thermometer.   [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There has been a rise in stigma and hate crimes against Chinese and other Asian Americans, as well as people who were in quarantine. This is due to lack of knowledge around how COVID-19 spreads, a need to blame someone, fears about disease and death, and gossip that spreads rumors and myths.  Stigma hurts everyone. It creates more fear and anger towards ordinary people, instead of the disease that is causing the problem, or towards systems that are not helping people to get the treatment and screening they need. Sharing facts about how COVID-19 actually spreads can help stop stigma.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
questionText: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
answerOriginal: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies.   If the family member, domestic partner, next of kin, or legal representative is in a different country than the deceased person, they should call the Department of State's Office of Overseas Citizens Services in Washington DC, from 8a-5p ET, Mon-Fri, at 888-407-4747 (toll-free) or 202-501-444. For emergency assistance after working hours or on weekends/holidays, call the Department of State switchboard at 202-647-4000 and ask to speak with the Overseas Citizens Services duty officer.   In addition to these steps above, the in-country of closest US embassy can also provide assistance.
answerText: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies.   If the family member, domestic partner, next of kin, or legal representative is in a different country than the deceased person, they should call the Department of State's Office of Overseas Citizens Services in Washington DC, from 8a-5p ET, Mon-Fri, at 888-407-4747 (toll-free) or 202-501-444. For emergency assistance after working hours or on weekends/holidays, call the Department of State switchboard at 202-647-4000 and ask to speak with the Overseas Citizens Services duty officer.   In addition to these steps above, the in-country of closest US embassy can also provide assistance.

questionOriginal: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
questionText: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
answerOriginal: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19. We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads and if a deceased body can transmit the virus. One could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes).   Try to avoid kissing washing, and shrouding the body. If washing and shrouding the body are important in your culture or religion, work with your community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff to try to reduce exposure as much as possible. People who conduct these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, more personal protective equipment may be needed, such as disposable gowns, goggles, and face masks.

questionOriginal: What are key messages for a mother who wants to breastfeed but is scared about passing COVID-19 to her infant?
questionText: What are key messages for a mother who wants to breastfeed but is scared about passing COVID-19 to her infant?
answerOriginal: As part of counseling, a mother’s anxiety about COVID-19 should be acknowledged and responded to with the following messages: - COVID-19 has not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and there is no evidence so far that the virus is transmitted through breastfeeding. - Newborns and infants are at low risk of COVID-19 infection.  - Breastfeeding and skin-to-skin contact reduces the risk of death in newborns and young infants and provide lifelong health and development benefits. Breastfeeding also reduces the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for the mother.
answerText: As part of counseling, a mother’s anxiety about COVID-19 should be acknowledged and responded to with the following messages: - COVID-19 has not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and there is no evidence so far that the virus is transmitted through breastfeeding. - Newborns and infants are at low risk of COVID-19 infection.  - Breastfeeding and skin-to-skin contact reduces the risk of death in newborns and young infants and provide lifelong health and development benefits. Breastfeeding also reduces the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for the mother.

questionOriginal: Is it advisable for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 who is breastfeeding, to give a ‘top-up’ with infant formula milk?
questionText: Is it advisable for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 who is breastfeeding, to give a ‘top-up’ with infant formula milk?
answerOriginal: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 and is breastfeeding, there is no need to provide a top up with an infant formula milk. Giving a top up will reduce the amount of milk given by a mother. Mothers who breastfeed should be counseled and supported to ensure positioning and attachment gives adequate milk production.

questionOriginal: Do the results of COVID-19 testing make any difference to infant and young child feeding recommendations?
questionText: Do the results of COVID-19 testing make any difference to infant and young child feeding recommendations?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 testing does not have any immediate connection for decisions on infant and young child feeding. However, confirmation of COVID-19 means that a mother should start appropriate recommended hygiene practices for the period that she is likely to be infective i.e. while symptomatic or through the 14 days after the start of symptoms, whichever is longer.

questionOriginal: If a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 was unable to breastfeed because she was too ill or because of another illness, when can she start to breastfeed again?
questionText: If a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 was unable to breastfeed because she was too ill or because of another illness, when can she start to breastfeed again?
answerOriginal: A mother can start to breastfeed when she feels well enough to do so. There is no fixed time interval to wait after confirmed/suspected COVID-19. There is no evidence that breastfeeding changes the clinical course of COVID-19 in a mother. She should be supported in her general health and nutrition to ensure full recovery. She should also be supported to initiate breastfeeding or relactate.

She should also be supported to initiate breastfeeding or relactate.

questionOriginal: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is not able to breastfeed or to express breastmilk, can wet-nursing be recommended?
questionText: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is not able to breastfeed or to express breastmilk, can wet-nursing be recommended?
answerOriginal: Wet-nursing may be an option depending on acceptability to mothers/families, national guidelines, cultural acceptability, availability of wet-nurses and services to support mothers and wet nurses. • In settings where HIV is common, wet nurses should undergo HIV counseling and rapid testing where available. In the absence of testing, if feasible undertake HIV risk assessment. If HIV risk assessment or counseling is not possible, continue with wet nursing.  • Prioritize wet nurses for the youngest infants.

In the absence of testing, if feasible undertake HIV risk assessment. If HIV risk assessment or counseling is not possible, continue with wet nursing.  • Prioritize wet nurses for the youngest infants.

questionOriginal: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is expressing her milk for her baby, are there extra measures needed when handling the breastmilk pump, milk storage containers or feeding utensils?
questionText: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is expressing her milk for her baby, are there extra measures needed when handling the breastmilk pump, milk storage containers or feeding utensils?
answerOriginal: Even when COVID-19 is not a consideration, breastmilk pumps, milk storage containers and feeding utensils need to be appropriately cleaned after every use. • Wash the pump/containers after every use with liquid soap, e.g. dishwashing liquid and warm water. Rinse after with hot water for 10-15 seconds. • Some breast pumps parts can be put in the top rack of a dishwasher (if available). Check the instruction manual before doing this.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to give expressed breastmilk from a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?
questionText: Is it safe to give expressed breastmilk from a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 virus has yet not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19.
answerText: The COVID-19 virus has yet not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Is it necessary for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 to wash her breast before she breastfeeds directly or before expressing milk?
questionText: Is it necessary for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 to wash her breast before she breastfeeds directly or before expressing milk?
answerOriginal: She should gently wash the breast with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds prior to feeding. It is not necessary to wash the breast before every breastfeed or prior to expressing milk if the mother has not been exposed to COVID-19.
answerText: She should gently wash the breast with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds prior to feeding. It is not necessary to wash the breast before every breastfeed or prior to expressing milk if the mother has not been exposed to COVID-19.

questionOriginal: If a mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 does not have a medical face mask should she still breastfeed?
questionText: If a mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 does not have a medical face mask should she still breastfeed?
answerOriginal: Mothers should continue breastfeeding. The transmission of the virus through breastmilk and breastfeeding has not been detected. Mothers should still continue wearing a mask if available to reduce the chance of viral droplets being spread to her baby.
answerText: Mothers should continue breastfeeding. The transmission of the virus through breastmilk and breastfeeding has not been detected. Mothers should still continue wearing a mask if available to reduce the chance of viral droplets being spread to her baby.

questionOriginal: What are the hygiene recommendations for a breastfeeding mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19?
questionText: What are the hygiene recommendations for a breastfeeding mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If a mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 she should: - Wash hands frequently with soap and water or use alcohol based hand rub, especially before touching the baby - Wear a medical mask while feeding. It is important to replace masks as soon as they become damp, dispose of masks immediately, not reuse a mask, and not touch the front of the mask but untie it from behind - Sneeze or cough into a tissue, immediately dispose of it and use alcohol-based hand rub or wash hands again with soap and clean water - Regularly clean and disinfect surfaces

questionText: Following delivery, should a baby still be immediately placed skin-to-skin and breastfed if the mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?

questionOriginal: Should mothers breastfeed in communities where COVID-19 is prevalent?
questionText: Should mothers breastfeed in communities where COVID-19 is prevalent?
answerOriginal: Breastfeeding improves survival and provides health and development advantages to babies. Breastfeeding also improves the health of mothers. There is no reason to avoid or stop breastfeeding.
answerText: Breastfeeding improves survival and provides health and development advantages to babies. Breastfeeding also improves the health of mothers. There is no reason to avoid or stop breastfeeding.

questionText: Can COVID-19 be passed through breastfeeding?

questionOriginal: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19, is infant formula milk safer for infants?
questionText: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19, is infant formula milk safer for infants?
answerOriginal: There are always risks associated with giving infant formula milk to newborns and infants in all settings. The risks associated with giving infant formula milk are increased whenever home and community conditions are affected. The numerous benefits of breastfeeding significantly outweigh the potential risks of transmission and illness that occur with the COVID-19 virus.

questionOriginal: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
questionText: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
answerOriginal: In most places, you can still go for a walk during a shelter in place order as long as you follow your local state or county's rules. Here are a few tips:  -Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people -Limit how long you will be outside, especially if there is a COVID-19 outbreak near you -Do not go to places where there are lots of people or crowds  This may not be allowed if you are in a location with strict quarantine measures. If you are or might be infected with COVID-19, you should not go for a walk outside, and should be self-isolating or in quarantine.   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]]

questionOriginal: Why do recommendations for mothers with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and their infants seem different from social distancing recommendations for the general population?
questionText: Why do recommendations for mothers with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and their infants seem different from social distancing recommendations for the general population?
answerOriginal: The recommendations for adults and older children to maintain social distancing are to reduce contact with persons not showing symptoms who have COVID-19 so that the virus does not spread. The recommendations for babies and young children whose mothers have confirmed or suspected COVID-19 infection is to improve the survival, health and development of their newborns and infants.

questionOriginal: Can my pet (dog, cat, other animal) get COVID-19?
questionText: Can my pet (dog, cat, other animal) get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Right now, we don't know of any clear cases of the virus passing from people to their pets. There was a tiger in a zoo in New York City that seems to have gotten COVID-19 from its caretakers. To be safe, wash your hands before and after touching animals.   Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal, you should:  1. Avoid close contact with them. Do not snuggle or kiss them, let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed. 2. Avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals. Cover your coughs and sneezes. 3. Have another member of your household care for your animals, if you can. 4. If it's not possible to have someone else care for your animal, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them. 5. Limit your animal's contact with other people and animals. Tthis may mean keeping them indoors.  We might learn more about human to animal spread in the future. Talk to your pet's doctor if you are worried about your pet's health.

questionOriginal: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
questionText: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Right now, we don't know of any higher risk due to being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19 as long as you stay 6 feet (2 meters) away. That being said, for now we must all avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as we can to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What if my family member traveled from a country or had a layover in a country with widespread or sustained transmission in the last 14 days?
questionText: What if my family member traveled from a country or had a layover in a country with widespread or sustained transmission in the last 14 days?
answerOriginal: Your family member should:  Seek medical care right away. Before they go to a doctor’s office or emergency room, call ahead and tell them about their recent travel and symptoms. Avoid contact with others. Not travel while sick. They should cover their mouth and nose with a tissue or their sleeve (not their hands) when coughing or sneezing. Wash hands often with soap and water for 15-20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.

Wash hands often with soap and water for 15-20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
questionText: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
answerOriginal: If you do not have any symptoms, you will be asked to:  1. Self-quarantine for 14 days after you get home.  2. Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with health problems who are higher risk of severe illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or trouble breathing. 4. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol. 5. Cover your mouth and nose with your arm or a tissue when coughing or sneezing. Throw away the tissue right after and wash your hands.   If you start to have symptoms like a cough or fever within the 14 days:  1. Continue to self-isolate from others.  2. Call a healthcare professional or a public health authority and tell them your symptoms and travel history. Follow their instructions.  3.  If your symptoms are severe - such as pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away, trouble breathing, feeling confused or unable to arouse, or lips or face that look blue, seek medical care right away. Please contact your medical provider if you have questions about your health and safety.   [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Should I avoid traveling?
questionText: Should I avoid traveling?
answerOriginal: If you are thinking about traveling, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice before you go. It is important to limit travel as much as possible.   If you think you need to travel, please go through these questions:   1. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you're going?  If it is, you may be more likely to get infected if you travel there than if you stay at home.   2. Will you or the people who you are traveling with be in close contact with others during your trip?  Your risk increases in crowded settings, especially closed-in settings that do not have good circulation. This includes conferences, concerts, etc.   3. Are you or your travel companion more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  People at higher risk for severe disease are older adults and people of any age with serious chronic medical conditions (e.g. heart disease, lung disease, diabetes). If you are at higher risk, avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.   4. Do you have a plan for taking time off from work or school, in case you are told to stay home for 14 days for self-monitoring or if you get sick with COVID-19?  You may be asked to take time off, and be unable to go to work or school until you are considered non-infectious.   5. Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If you get sick with COVID-19 while you travel, your family, friends, loved ones may be at risk of getting sick. People who are older and who have health problems are more likely to get very sick.  6. Is COVID-19 spreading where I live when I return from travel?  Even if you don't feel sick right now, you could pass on COVID-19 to others during travel without knowing it. This is very important if you'll be in contact with people who are older adults or have a severe chronic health problem. These people are at higher risk of getting very sick.   It is important to go through these questions to decide if it makes sense to travel.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there Covid in my area?]]

questionOriginal: Is it true that veterinarians cannot get supplies like surgical gowns, gloves and masks?
questionText: Is it true that veterinarians cannot get supplies like surgical gowns, gloves and masks?
answerOriginal: Personal protective equipment (PPE) for human healthcare professionals is very important. Since PPE is needed in person to person settings, this may cause a shortage in other health care settings. Some veterinary practices have donated their supplies to help hospitals. Each veterinarian's supply store will be different. If you have concerns, you should contact your veternarian directly to as about their safety plans.  [[Would you like more information about What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?]]

questionOriginal: My pet has health problems and goes to the vet regularly for treatment. Should I be doing anything different to manage their health during the COVID-19 outbreak?
questionText: My pet has health problems and goes to the vet regularly for treatment. Should I be doing anything different to manage their health during the COVID-19 outbreak?

questionOriginal: If my pet has been vaccinated for a species-specific cornavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
questionText: If my pet has been vaccinated for a species-specific cornavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: It is hard to predict whether a pet who has had one type of vaccine will be more or less likely to get a new virus. The best thing to do is to treat pets as you would other human family members – do not let pets interact with people or animals outside the household. If a person inside the household becomes sick, isolate that person from everyone else, including pets. questionOriginal: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
questionText: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
answerOriginal: If there is an outbreak in your community, you should:  1. Stay calm! 2. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people 3. Stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation through your local health department 4. Wash your hands 5. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissue 6. Clean surfaces that people touch a lot  Please stay home if you are sick, and limit contact with others as much as you can.  Notify your workplace as soon as possible if your regular work schedule will need to change. Ask to work from home or take leave if your or someone in your home gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms or if your child's school is dismissed.   If you live alone and have a chronic health problem, please reach out to friends, family, loved ones, and healthcare providers. Also ask them to check in on you. Stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
questionText: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. If possible, have the sick household member use a separate room and bathroom. Try to have the sick family member stay away from other people as much as they can. Clean and sanitize your hands and home regularly.  Don't share personal items like utensils, foods, and drinks.  The sick person should stay at home except to get medical care. Please contact a health care provider right away if they have one of these severe symptoms: -Trouble breathing  -Shortness of breath  -Chest pain or pressure that won't go away -Feeling very tired or unable to wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  Please keep in mind that this is not the full list. If someone in your house has one of these severe symptoms or something that worries you, please contact your medical provider.

questionOriginal: Why do I have to stay at home?
questionText: Why do I have to stay at home?
answerOriginal: Staying at home and using "social distancing" helps stop the virus from spreading quickly. This helps to reduce the burden on healthcare systems, as there are not enough hospital workers and beds if too many people get sick at once.  Social distancing means staying farther away from other people and avoiding groups of people. Since COVID-19 mostly spreads from person-to-person interactions, staying at least 6 feet away from other people can help stop the spread. It is important to use social distancing because people can spread COVID-19 even if they feel fine. It is especially important to use social distancing to protect people who are more likely to get very sick from the disease.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?
questionText: How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?
answerOriginal: In an experiment, scientists found that the virus could live:  -On plastic for up to 72 hours (3 days) -On stainless steel for up to 48 hours (2 days) -On cardboard for up to 24 hours (1 day) -On copper for up to 4 hours -In the air for up to 3 hours  Scientists still need to do more research to find out if these results also apply to the real world.  It is important to clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot.You should also wash your hands frequently with soap and water or use a hand sanitizer with at leat 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
questionText: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
answerOriginal: Yes. We are still learning about how easily COVID-19 can transfer through the air. Small droplets can probably stay in the air for a short time after someone coughs or sneezes and those could infect someone. Also, some medical procedures can cause very small droplets that stay in the air for a longer time.  Scientists think that the main way you could get infected is if you were in close contact with an infected person and had your mouth, nose, or eyes exposed to infected respiratory droplets.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-isolation?
questionText: What is self-isolation?
answerOriginal: Self-isolation means that people who are sick stay away from those who are not sick. This helps to keep the disease from spreading. If someone has asked you to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you have to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands a lot -Keep track of your symptoms  Go here to read more about how you should self-isolate, visit this page: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What are respiratory droplets?
questionText: What are respiratory droplets?
answerOriginal: Respiratory droplets are little drops that come from your nose or mouth when you sneeze, cough, talk, or breathe. They can stay in the air, or they can be passed from one person to another by touching commonly used surfaces such as door knobs, elevator buttons and faucets. questionText: What is a state of emergency? Does it indicate the severity of a situation?

questionOriginal: What is a biological medical product or a biologic?
questionText: What is a biological medical product or a biologic?
answerOriginal: A biological medical product (sometimes called "biologic") is a medicine made from natural sources or using biotechnology or other new technology. Some types of biologics are vaccines, blood, and other things made from human cells. They can come from humans, animals, or microorganisms. They can be made of sugars, proteins, and/or nucleic acids, or they can be living things.  [[Would you like more information about What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 can spread in a few different ways. It can spread from person to person if you inhale an infected person's respiratory droplets when they sneezes, coughs, or talk. It can also spead if you touch something that an infected person has touched, like a door knob, elevator button, or bathroom faucet.  That's why it's important to wash your hands, avoid touching your face, and practice social distancing to avoid getting sick. That's why it's also important to self-isolate and wear a mask around other household members if you are sick to avoid infecting other people.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about Does hand-washing kill the virus?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-monitoring?
questionText: What is self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: Self-monitoring means that people should monitor themselves for fever by taking their temperatures twice a day and paying attention if they begin coughing or have trouble breathing. If they start to get symptoms during this self-monitoring period, they should self-isolate, limit their contact with others, and seek medical advice by telephone if possible.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
questionText: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: The difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation is based on whether you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or not. If you may have been exposed to COVID-19 but don't have symptoms, you should self-monitor. If you have been diagnosed with COVID-19, you should self-isolate.  You need to self-monitor if you have no symptoms but may have been exposed to COVID-19 in the last 14 days or are in close contact with older adults, people who are medically vulnerable or have been asked to do so by your Public Health Authority. Self-monitoring means you should:  -Monitor yourself for 14 days for symptoms like fever, cough, and trouble breathing -Stay at home -Avoid crowded places -Stay at least 6 feet away from others as much as you can -Wash your hands frequently  You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Keep checking your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What is social distancing?
questionText: What is social distancing?
answerOriginal: Social distancing means staying home and limiting contact with other people as much as you can. Social distancing is important because it reduces the spread of illness. You might need to change your habits to do social distancing well. For example:  -Avoid groups of people as much as you can -Don't shake hands or touch people to greet them -Don't go to crowded places such as concerts, arenas, conferences, or festivals -Stay away from people at high risk for severe symptoms, such as older people and those in poor health -Stay at least 2 arms' length (about 6 feet) away from others.  For example, if you need to buy groceries, limit this to once a week. If you go on walks, stay at least 6 feet away from others.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
answerOriginal: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. Scientists are still studying how long coronavirus lives on surfaces. In general, you should practice good hygiene and food safety practices. This means cleaning surfaces that are used a lot, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food. questionOriginal: What is self-quarantine?
questionText: What is self-quarantine?
answerOriginal: Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days.   Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.
