questionOriginal: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
questionText: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
answerOriginal: If the infected person lives with others, it is important to keep them apart from others as much as possible. This means they should stay in another room as much as they can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible.  If you are living with someone who is infected, you should:  -Avoid sharing household items like dishes, cups, towels, and bedding -Wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol -Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot -Wash laundry frequently and thoroughly -If you have pets, the infected person should not care for them -Don't have visitors in your home

questionOriginal: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?

That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days. Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]
answerText: You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation is a health care term that means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Continue to monitor your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days. Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
questionText: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
answerOriginal: Yes, the virus can spread from person to person during incubation period. The “incubation period” means the time between catching the virus and beginning to have symptoms of the disease. If you may have been exposed to the virus and do not have any symptoms, please self-quarantine. If you are having COVID-19 symptoms, please self-isolate. questionOriginal: How long do people have to isolate for?
questionText: How long do people have to isolate for?
answerOriginal: How long you should be isolated for varies on a case-by-case basis. If you have been sick with COVID-19 and have been in isolation, you should talk to your healthcare provider to decide when you can be released from isolation. Your doctor will look for signs that:  -You are fever-free without taking fever-reducing medication -You no longer show symptoms -Sometimes, your doctor might recommend testing respiratory samples to decide if you can be released from isolation  Once you have been released from isolation, then you are no longer considered to be likely to infect other people.   [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
questionText: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answerOriginal: Personal protective equipment (PPE) are types of equipment worn to reduce the chance of someone getting a workplace injury or illness. Examples include gloves, safety glasses, shoes, earplugs or muffs, hard hats, respirators, coveralls, etc.   PPE is very important during this pandemic because there are not enough face masks for frontline health workers.  [[Would you like more information about What are N95 respirators/masks?]] [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]]

questionOriginal: What are N95 respirators/masks?
questionText: What are N95 respirators/masks?
answerOriginal: This is a type of personal protective equipment that forms a tight seal around the nose and mouth to avoid airborne particles and fluid from entering. These masks are not "one size fits all" so people who depend on them for the job must get fit-tested before using them.   It is not recommended that the general public wear  N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?]]

questionOriginal: Can we use fabric masks to prevent the spread?
questionText: Can we use fabric masks to prevent the spread?
answerOriginal: Face masks, including fabric ones, are likely only helpful in preventing people who have COVID-19 from spreading it to others. If you wear a cloth mask, you should still use the same social distancing measures as you would if you were not wearing a mask. This means you should stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people, wash your hands frequently, and avoid touching your face or eyes.  When wearing a mask, make sure it covers your nose and mouth. Wash the mask after you use it every time. When handling the mask, act as though the front of the mask is contaminated. Don't touch the front of the mask when you take it off or put it on.  It is not recommended that the general public wear surgical or N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra surgical or N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]

questionOriginal: Will COVID-19 go away like the 1918 influenza and SARS did?

questionOriginal: What is the impact of COVID-19?
questionText: What is the impact of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is likely impact our lives in many ways. On the community level, this oubreak might lead to a decrease in polarization, more trust in science, and less individualism. On a lifestyle-level, this outbreak has moved even more of our activities online and might be a new boon to virtual reality. In terms of our health, there is likely to be a rise on telemedicine and an opening stronger family care. It is quite obvious that the global economy has taken a big toll due to COVID-19. Some experts say that there will be more restraints on mass consumption, stronger domestic supply chains, and a widening of the inequality gap, following the pandemic.

questionOriginal: What is SARS-CoV?
questionText: What is SARS-CoV?
answerOriginal: SARS-CoV stands for "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-associated CoronaVirus." It is a virus that can cause serious problems with breathing and the lungs. It is different from the virus that has caused the COVID-19 pandemic.   The SARS-CoV virus was first found in Asia in 2003 and last known human case was in China in 2004. SARS-CoV spreads through close person to person contact and caused flu like symptoms.   [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: What is MERS-CoV?
questionText: What is MERS-CoV?
answerOriginal: MERS-CoV is one type of coronavirus. It is different type from the type of coronavirus that causes COVID-19. MERS-CoV stands for "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome- associated Coronavirus."  The first cases of MERS-CoV were seen in 2012 in Saudi Arabia. MERS-CoV symptoms are fever, cough, and shortness of breath. People with this disease usually do not get sick from one another unless they are in very close contact. questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
answerOriginal: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. But some studies show that the virus can last on surfaces, so it is possible that someone could get the virus by touching a surface that has the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose, or eyes. questionOriginal: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The most important thing is to wash your hands. Use soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, or before or after eating or making food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty. If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol.     Here are some other things you can do to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19:    - Clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot, like tables, counters, light switches, door knobs, and cabinet handles.   - Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues and throw the tissue away.   - Stay at home if you are sick.   - Don't get too close to people who are sick.   - If "social distancing" measures are in effect where you are, be sure to follow them.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Can you smoke weed/cannabis during COVID-19?

questionOriginal: Has COVID-19 mutated?
questionText: Has COVID-19 mutated?
answerOriginal: Like most viruses, the virus that causes COVID-19 is also mutating, which means changing its RNA structure. It is normal for viruses to mutate.  Right now, the mutations are probably not changing how the virus spreads or makes people sick.

questionOriginal: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
questionText: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
answerOriginal: The death rates are different between countries for a few reasons. The main reason is because some countries have tested more people than others.   Death rates can seem higher in countries where fewer people are tested. That's because death rates compare the number of people who have died from a disease to the number of people who have the disease, whether they die or not. When countries only test patients who are sick enough to go to the hospital and are not testing those who are less sick, this makes death rates seem higher than they are.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
questionText: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
answerOriginal: The main differences between viruses and bacteria are:  1. Viruses need to infect other cells to reproduce. They can't reproduce on their own. However, bacteria can reproduce on their own. 2. Viruses usually can't survive on their own as long as bacteria. 3. Viruses are much smaller than bacteria. 4. Most viruses cause disease. Some bacteria cause disease and some do not. 5. Viruses are usually more specific than bacteria about the kinds of cells that they attack in the body. For example, the virus that causes COVID-19 mostly affects cells in the respiratory system (the parts of the body involved in breathing)  [[Would you like more information about What is a virus?]]

questionOriginal: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
questionText: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
answerOriginal: There are a few reasons why people are very concerned about COVID-19. First, it is a new virus that humans have never had before. Our bodies haven't learned how to fight it off yet. Second, the virus is very infectious and has spread quickly around the world. Third, about 1 out of every 5 people who gets COVID-19 needs medical care in a hospital. Some hospitals will have trouble caring for this many sick people at the same time. Fourth, doctors and scientists still don't know very much about COVID-19 or how to treat it yet. Everyone is learning more every day.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for serious illness?]]

questionOriginal: What is a virus?
questionText: What is a virus?
answerOriginal: A virus is a very small particle that infect other cells. Viruses that infect people can make them sick.  Viruses are tiny, smaller than bacteria or fungi. They are small pieces of genetic material (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein shell. Viruses cannot survive long on their own. They need to use a living cell to live and reproduce. Once a virus enters a cell, it takes over that cell and uses it to make more viruses that go on to infect other cells.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: How can I get tested if I am asymptomatic?
questionText: How can I get tested if I am asymptomatic?
answerOriginal: If you do not have symptoms such as fever, cough or shortness of breath, you probably do not need to be tested for COVID-19 at this time. Getting tested usually will NOT help you get better treatment. You should continue to stay at home as much as you can and follow social distancing guidelines, even if you do not feel sick.  Please contact your provider if you begin to havesymptoms of COVID-19 or if you have any changes in your health.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Do the test results work if you don't have symptoms?
questionText: Do the test results work if you don't have symptoms?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 test usually does not help most people without symptoms, although your health care provider might decide to test you if you were exposed to an infected person. Sometimes you can test positive if you are infected but don't have symptoms yet. But no test is perfect. You could also get a "false negative" result. This means that you could still have the disease even if the test result is negative (normal).   You should continue to stay at home if possible and follow social distancing guidelines, even if you do not have symptoms.  [[What is social distancing?]] [[What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[What is self-monitoring?]]

questionOriginal: How often should I take my temperature?
questionText: How often should I take my temperature?
answerOriginal: If you think you could have been exposed or infected with COVID-19, take your temperature two times a day (morning and night) every day for 14 days. questionOriginal: How long is the treatment?
questionText: How long is the treatment?
answerOriginal: At this time, there is no  treatment for COVID-19. Most people who get COVID-19 will recover on their own or with treatment with over-the-counter cold or flu medications. People who have more severe illness might need to go to the hospital for care. The length of time to recovery varies from one person to another. Most people take about two weeks to recover from COVID-19. People with severe symptoms or other conditions might take between 3 and 6 weeks to recover.

questionOriginal: Should I take hydroxychloroquinine?
questionText: Should I take hydroxychloroquinine?
answerOriginal: You should not take hydroxychloroquine unless a doctor prescribed it to you for a specific health issue. Scientists and doctors don't know for sure if hydroxychloroquine works against COVID-19 and they don't know how safe it is. It has some side effects like stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, and headache. It can also have dangerous side effects if you take the wrong dose.

questionOriginal: Should I take chloroquine?
questionText: Should I take chloroquine?
answerOriginal: Chloroquine Phosphate is a medicine that people usually use to prevent or treat malaria. As of April 2020, it has not been approved to treat COVID-19. questionOriginal: What kind of medicine can I take to help ease the symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: What kind of medicine can I take to help ease the symptoms of COVID-19?

questionOriginal: How to treat coronavirus naturally?
questionText: How to treat coronavirus naturally?
answerOriginal: If you are at home with mild symptoms, you may be able to relieve symptoms by getting extra rest and sleep, drinking enough liquids to stay hydrated, staying warm, and using a humidifier or taking a hot shower to help a sore throat and cough. If you are thinking about taking any supplement or natural medicine, please talk to your healthcare provider first to make sure there are no negative side effects. Right now, there is no evidence that any supplements or natural medicines can treat COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You can reduce your risk of getting sick by:  1. Staying at home as much as you can. Only go out when you really need to (for groceries, for example) 2. If you do go out, keep at least 6 foot (2 meter) distance between you and other people. 3. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or makng food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty.  4. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. 5. Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).   If you or someone in your family gets sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Can I donate blood?

answerOriginal: You can donate blood as long as you are not sick. Donated blood is always needed. If you are well and eligible, please consider donating. questionOriginal: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
questionText: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
answerOriginal: Since the virus has spread all over the world, there is no reason to be more concerned about a product from China compared to a product shipped from somewhere else. Most cases of coronavirus spread through close contact with an infected person. It is much less likely to get it from touching a surface like a package. To be very careful, you could wipe down the package, wait for a few days before you open the package, and wash your hands with soap and water after touching the package.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
questionText: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
answerOriginal: First, please remember that surgical masks should only be used by health workers, caretakers, and people who have COVID-19 symptoms like a cough or a fever.  To put on a surgical mask, you should: 1. Wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer BEFORE touching the mask 2. Look at the mask for tears and holes. 3. Find which side is the top side. If the mask has a metal strip or stiff edge, that is the top side. 4. Check that the right side of the mask is facing away from you. The colored side should face away from you. 5. Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or the stiff edge of the mask so that it molds to the shape of your nose. 6. Pull down the bottom of the mask so it covers your mouth and chin  To take off and dispose of a surgical mask: 1. Remove the elastic loops from behind your ears, while keeping the mask away from your face and clothes. This is to avoid touching potentially contaminated surfaces of the mask 2. Throw the mask away in a closed trash can right after use 3. Wash your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after touching or throwing away the mask.    [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
questionText: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
answerOriginal: If you are high risk and there is an outbreak near you, you should: 1. Stay home as much as you can  2. Stock up on supplies like nonperishable foods and medicines  3. Limit travel as much as you can  4. Watch for symptoms and emergency signs    If you must interact with others, you should: 1. Keep at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people  2. Stay away from crowds  3. Stay away from people who are sick  4. Wash your hands often with soap and water  5. Don't touch your face    If you get sick, please call your doctor. questionOriginal: What does it mean if someone is being monitored for COVID-19?
questionText: What does it mean if someone is being monitored for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Monitoring for COVID-19 means looking for signs of illness in people who could have been exposed to COVID-19. questionOriginal: Do vaccines against pneumonia protect you against the new coronavirus?
questionText: Do vaccines against pneumonia protect you against the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Different types of viruses and bacteria can cause pneumonia. The virus that causes COVID-19 is a new type and needs its own vaccine. So, if you had a different vaccine that protects against some types of pneumonia, it will not protect you against pneumonia caused by the new coronavirus. You should continue to get routine vaccines that your doctor recommends.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
questionText: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There is currently no vaccine or treatment  for COVID-19, and it might take some time to make one. Right now, scientists are still studying vaccines and some drug treatments to see if they are safe and if they work.  Luckily, most people who get COVID-19 will recover on their own or with treatment with over-the-counter cold or flu medications. Do NOT try to prevent or treat your COVID-19 symptoms using drugs like antibiotics. Talk to your doctor before starting a new medication.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: In general, a negative or normal result means that the virus that causes COVID-19 was not found in the sample. But sometimes if a person has COVID-19 in the early stages, they could test negative at first, but test positive later on, when there is more virus present. You healthcare provider can help decide if you should be tested again.  [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a facemask and an N95 respirator?
questionText: What is the difference between a facemask and an N95 respirator?
answerOriginal: An N95 respirator is a special type of mask that filters very small particles in the air. You need to get a fit test to make sure that the mask fits well and works. The "N95" means that the respirator blocks at least 95 percent of very small (0.3 micron) particles when tested.  It is not recommended that the general public wear  N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.   [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a mask?]] [[Would you like more information about Can we use fabric masks to prevent the spread?]]

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 kill people?
questionText: How does COVID-19 kill people?
answerOriginal: Most people don't die from COVID-19. But COVID-19 can kill people by causing lung infection (pneumonia) and swelling (inflammation). When the immune system tries to fight off the pneumonia, this can lead to too much inflammation and damage to the lungs. When this happens, not enough oxygen goes to important organs like the liver, kidney, and brain. If the lung damage is too bad and not enough oxygen gets to the rest of the body, this can cause organ failure and death.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
questionText: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
answerOriginal: The virus that causes COVID-19 is very susceptible to soaps. So when you wash clothes, use detergent. The CDC says it is fine to wash an infected person’s clothes with those of someone who is not ill. The CDC advises using your regular laundry detergent and then drying the clothes thoroughly at the warmest temperature recommended on the clothing label.

questionOriginal: Can you be re-infected with COVID-19?
questionText: Can you be re-infected with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Experts are still studying whether you can be re-infected with COVID-19. With other types of coronavirus, experts say that patients are immune to the specific virus for months or even years, but we need more research to tell if this is the case for COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
questionText: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
answerOriginal: Hand-washing is one of the best ways to keep yourself and your family from getting sick. Washing your hands well can remove all tarces of the virus on your hands. To wash your hands well,  use soap and water for at least 20 seconds.   Make sure to wash your hands:  - After blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing - After using the restroom - Before or after eating or making food - After being in a public place - After touching things that many other people have touched like door handles or tables  If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol. However, hand sanitizers do not get rid of all types of germs, so it is best to wash your hands as soon as you can.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
questionText: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Herd immunity is not the only way to control COVID-19.   Herd immunity is when enough of the population is immune to an infectious disease that the disease will not spread easily from person to person. This could happen either because most people are vaccinated for the disease or because they were sick before and are now immune. For COVID-19, that would mean that enough people would have to recover from the disease and become immune to reduce the person-to-person spread since there is not a vaccine yet.  The other way of controlling the spread of COVID-19 is to practice social distancing and frequent hand-washing. This helps to prevent too many people from getting sick with COVID-19 at once, which could lead to more sick people than hospitals can handle.   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about Can you be re-infected with COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Will high temperatures or heat kill COVID-19?
questionText: Will high temperatures or heat kill COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Hot water can kill germs, but it has to be very hot - too hot for humans to bear without injuring themselves. Being out in the sun or hot weather, taking long baths, or using hand dryers will not prevent you from getting COVID-19. Also, the virus is still spreading in countries with hot weather. questionOriginal: Can the new coronavirus be transmitted through mosquito bites?
questionText: Can the new coronavirus be transmitted through mosquito bites?
answerOriginal: So far, there is no evidence that the virus spreads through mosquitoes. The new virus spreads mostly through droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or through saliva or discharge from the nose. To protect yourself, clean your hands as much as you can with with soap and water or an alcohol based hand rub. Also, avoid close contact with anyone who is coughing and sneezing.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If you have one of these symptoms, you should call 911 or emergency medical services to seek care right away:  -Trouble breathing -Pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away -Feeling confused -Lips or face that look blue  If this is not an emergency, this symptom checker by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) can help you find out if you could have COVID-19. It can also help you decide what to do next. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/index.html  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Is the COVID-19 test anonymous?
questionText: Is the COVID-19 test anonymous?

Based on where you live, they may alert others who also might have been exposed so those people can take action to prevent further spread. questionOriginal: How can I get tested for COVID-19?
questionText: How can I get tested for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Getting tested usually will NOT help you get better treatment because currently there are no approved treatments for COVID-19. most people will not get very sick and can get better at home. Since there are not enough tests for everyone, it is important to make sure that people like health care workers and other high-risk groups can get tested first.  Please call your health care provider or the health department in your town or state to find out if you need to be tested.  [[Would you like more information about what are the symptoms of COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: When should I get tested for COVID-19?
questionText: When should I get tested for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Doctors and state health departments work to decide who should be tested based on their symptoms. Some of the factors that help decide if you need testing include your symptoms, how sick you are, if you have other health problems, and if you have contact with other vulnerable groups. Talk to your doctor if you think you need to be tested. questionOriginal: Is it dangerous to be outdoors?
questionText: Is it dangerous to be outdoors?
answerOriginal: Check your local government policies to see if it is ok for people to go outside for non-essential needs. If you go outside, continue to following social distancing and avoid close contact with others by staying at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people. If you are age 60 or over or have an underlying health condition, be extra careful about being around others. questionOriginal: What is the definition of close contact?
questionText: What is the definition of close contact?
answerOriginal: Close contact is defined as: a. Being within 6 feet (2 meters) of someone with COVID-19. Close contact can happen while caring for, living with, visiting, or sharing a health care waiting area or room with someone with COVID-19.  – or – b. Having direct contact with body fluids from someone with COVID-19, such as being coughed on.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: What is community mitigation?
questionText: What is community mitigation?
answerOriginal: Community mitigation are things that a community does to limit the spread of the virus. It includes:                                                                              1. Personal activities like staying home, covering coughs and sneezes and washing hands.  2. Community strategies like school closures, postponing social gatherings and social distancing.  3. Environmental activities like cleaning frequently touched surfaces and objects in homes, schools, and workplaces.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Can spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body kill the new coronavirus?
questionText: Can spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body kill the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body will not kill viruses that have already entered your body. Some of these sprays can be toxic to your skin and can cause rashes or chemical burns. You should carefully read the use and warning label on any product before using it on your body. Do not use household cleaners on your skin. Do not eat or drink household cleaners.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: How effective are thermal scanners in detecting people infected with the new coronavirus?
questionText: How effective are thermal scanners in detecting people infected with the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Thermal scanners detect fevers  (i.e. have a higher than normal body temperature). Some thermal scanners are better than others at detecting a fever. You should check with the manufacturer to learn how well a scanner works.   Thermal scanners cannot detect people who are infected but do not yet have a fever. It takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and get a fever.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Are hand dryers effective in killing the new coronavirus?
questionText: Are hand dryers effective in killing the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Hand dryers alone will not kill the COVID-19 virus. But cleaning your hands can! To protect yourself against COVID-19, you should frequently clean your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if you can't use soap and water. Once your hands are cleaned, dry them well with paper towels or a warm air dryer.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Does taking a hot bath prevent the new coronavirus disease?
questionText: Does taking a hot bath prevent the new coronavirus disease?
answerOriginal: Taking a hot bath will not keep you from catching COVID-19. Your body temperature stays around 36.5 to 37 degrees celsius, even if you take a hot bath or shower. Only very hot temperatures can kill the coronavirus. Do not take too hot of a shower, as it could burn you. The best way to protect yourself against COVID-19 is to frequently wash your hands. This helps to remove viruses on your hands that could infect you if you touch your eyes, mouth, and nose.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: I Got A Call, Text, Or Email Saying I Could Get Financial Help. Is It Legitimate?
questionText: I Got A Call, Text, Or Email Saying I Could Get Financial Help. Is It Legitimate?
answerOriginal: There have been reports that scammers pretend to be the government. They contact people by robocall, text message, email and other methods. These scammers say they can get people financial help during the pandemic, and then ask for money or personal information, like your bank account or credit card number. This is scam. Do not provide your credit card information or other personally identifying information over the phone.
